evidence_span: We did do analysis for hydrogen in our irradiated Zircaloy-2 materials after 273 days in 400°C steam.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_024_chunk8
evidence_span: The amount of hydrogen absorbed increased uniformly with increasing weight gain.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_024_chunk8
evidence_span: The hydrogen pickup fraction, calculated in the standard way, was quite high and decreased with increasing weight gain.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_024_chunk8
evidence_span: Pickup fraction for the highest fluence Material 8, which also had the highest weight gain, was 35%

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_024_chunk8
evidence_span: For the lowest fluence Material 1, it was 53%

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_024_chunk8
evidence_span: for unirradiated Material 20, it was 71%

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_024_chunk9
evidence_span: After high fluence, the dissolution process is well advanced and c-component dislocations are present in large numbers.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_024_chunk9
evidence_span: small precipitates lose almost all of their iron at very low fluence, less than $1 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \ \mathrm { n } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_024_chunk9
evidence_span: c-component dislocations do not appear until the fluence is considerably higher.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_024_chunk9
evidence_span: Postirradiation annealing of material irradiated to $1 . 2 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 6 } \mathrm { n } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$ $E > 1$ Mev) results in intergranular precipitation of iron, nickel-rich precipitates at $5 7 5 \mathrm { ‰}$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_024_chunk9
evidence_span: chromium, iron-rich precipitates at 625 to ${ \bf 7 5 0 ‰ }$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_024_chunk9
evidence_span: small changes in solute content can have large effects on corrosion.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_024_chunk9
evidence_span: Zircaloy-2 controlled chemistry tubes were fabricated using different tubeshell annealing temperatures and tube reduction schedules.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_024_chunk9
evidence_span: Samples with various processing histories were examined by TEM microscopy to characterize the intermetallic precipitate distributions and matrix solute concentration.
property_name: intermetallic precipitate distribution, matrix solute concentration

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_024_chunk9
evidence_span: Matrix concentration profiles across a $2 \cdot \mu \mathrm { m }$ length were obtained in scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) mode using an electron beam spot of approximately $0 . 0 7 \mu \mathrm { m }$ on high and low corrosion resistant material.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_024_chunk9
evidence_span: The influence of texture on corrosion was also examined by fabricating specimens with radial textures $( f _ { r } )$ values from approximately 0.3 to 0.6.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_024_chunk9
evidence_span: The tube reduction schedule has a very significant influence on nodular corrosion behavior.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_024_chunk9
evidence_span: High $f _ { r }$ on the final cladding suppressed the nodular corrosion behavior regardless of the precipitate size.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_024_chunk9
evidence_span: Micro-zones of solute segregation in the matrix were also detected above the solubility limits of $\pmb { \alpha }$ zirconium on some final cladding specimens.
